title: Rate cuts v dividends: borrowers twice as well off as shareholders
text:
"As the Reserve Bank Governor Philip Lowe pointed out recently: 'Lower interest rates put more money into the hands of the household sector and, at some point, this extra money gets spent and this helps the overall economy,'" Mr Frydenberg said.

"The RBA said just in August that 'bank funding costs have declined across the board' and 'the recent reductions in the overnight cash rate in Australia and the decline in interest rates right along the yield curve have reduced the costs of funding to historical lows for banks'"

What about savers?

While cutting rates further is bad news for savers and could result in an exodus of deposit funding for banks as savers place their money in equities offering higher returns but at higher risk, Dr Lowe says that is just tough luck.

"The underlying explanation for low interest rates globally is that the global appetite to save is high relative to the global appetite to invest. Like many things in economics, it comes down to supply and demand. When the global supply of savings is high relative to the global demand for funding to invest in new capital, the price of savings is going to be low."

But he says he hears the complaints.

"What about the savers, have we forgotten about them? I am reminded of this daily as people write to me telling me how the already low deposit rates are affecting their income.

"The many people who write to me saying how low interest rates are hurting their finances serve as a constant reminder of this. But, importantly, the board also recognises that monetary policy still works.

Advertisement

"It works to support employment, jobs and income growth across the economy. In doing so, these decisions will promote the collective economic welfare of the Australian people, which we need to remember is the ultimate goal of monetary policy."

Prime Minister Scott Morrison also doesn't buy into the pleading from big banks that lower profits would hamper economic growth more than if the banks cut rates and provided a stimulus to housing.

He accused the banks this week of "profiteering" after not passing on the Reserve Bank's full 25 basis point interest rate cut.

The pressure is also coming from competition regulator chairman Rod Sims, who has been angling for a new "deep dive" inquiry into the pricing power of the big four.

Labor MP Matt Thistlethwaite said: "The problem with banking in Australia at the moment is that in terms of the mortgage market, 80 per cent of the mortgages are held by the big four banks.

This week Liberal MP Tim Wilson sent questions to the big four as well as Bank of Queensland and others about how they were passing on the interest rate cuts.

“This is the problem of a low interest rate environment: deposit holders are squeezed, listed banks are squeezed on profitability, as are those relying on dividends and if full rate cuts aren’t passed through, stimulus is contained," Mr Wilson said.
description: A home loan borrower who also has an average shareholding in a bank would be at least twice as better off if the bank passed on all three of this year's 25 basis point cuts than if it did not.
